job_title: Nutrition Aide in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Great pay for part time ($14.xx starting) and the hours are great, especially if you are in school (6:45-3:15 or 3:15-8:15). Shifts are also easy to pick up if you want extra hours due to being extremely short staffed daily. Convenient location. My advice: apply as a casual so you can pick up as many shifts as you want and you wont be confined to working every other weekend and not being able to request days off.
cons: Poor management, difficult scheduling time off or trading with coworker, overworked because it is consistently understaffed. Every month management is adding duties to jobs, making the employee take on more and more, burning everyone out quickly. Management thinks they are better than employees, thus not helping out - will stand there criticizing you while all the employees are running around trying to get their dozen duties done. Most days you will not get breaks, barely getting your lunch.

job_title: Psychotherapist in Woodbury, MN
pros: Flexible. Good compensation. Pick your area if work.
cons: Some disorganization. Quick paperwork turn around expectations

job_title: Patient Financial Services
pros: A lot of great employees that are in desperate need of good management.
cons:
Horrible management- From top to bottom! FV clean them all out and start fresh!
Forced VBI- Note to HE. Don't bother telling me that it's not forced. It is. They count the number of ideas that you come up with each month. It's gone over in roundings and in yearly reviews. Ridiculous! It should be used voluntarily. It's crazy to think that employees can come up with ideas every month. Our group is always scrounging to come up with enough ideas to fill our quota. We will even use the need for a supply, such as I need a garbage can just to fill it.  If this VBI was such a great tool, why are we still millions in the hole. I know we have loss from the aging population, but that is not all. Don't forget, we can all see the number of claims sitting in work filters. If the VBI was so wonderful, the high number of claims wouldn't  be sitting in there. If you want to improve processes, and save time and money, stop paying all your employees to stand in a circle each morning for 15 minutes or longer going over the same useless questions, and stop forcing employees to waste time coming up with useless ideas. Use the VBI board as a voluntary tool that employees can use when they feel it is necessary, and limit the huddle to 1-2 times a week for any area that is not directly dealing with patients.

review_title: Not a Five-Star, nor a Four-Star, or Even a Three-Star Rating Company to Work for!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Some employees are invited to use three-stars for job-site ratings. It makes the most favorable review more believable for readers. This method also builds a slow but steady uptake in company ratings.
cons: When employees have complaints regarding the Management and have appointments with the Human Resource Department to discuss these issues, they shouldn’t be blindsided when walking into the H.R. department conference room - there sits across the table the scowling H.R. representative and the employees boss. The boss is grinning... the H.R. Rep moves across from the employee (and the H.R. Rep is still scowling) and says "We thoroughly investigated the complaint and we were unable to substantiate any of the issues mentioned. Because there is nothing illegal here, the complaint is now closed. “However," says the HR Rep with a furrowed brow, "job performance, or lack thereof, from employees are very concerning." As the H.R. Rep says this and opens a thick file and passes around copies of a three-page document titled "Performance Improvement Plan." The boss continues to sit there in silence, nodding and smirking. The employee is shocked and distraught and has difficulty remembering the details of what was said for the rest of the meeting. Almost an hour later the employee leaves the conference room in stunned silence, carrying a one-page document titled "Written Warning". The next day the employee called in sick and thought that resigning is now the only option. What just happened? Know this, HR exists first and foremost to protect the company’s interests. Pay attention to whom HR heads report to. It is often General Counsel, aka the lawyers.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Benefits were very very good
cons: Management could use some improvements

job_title: Charge RN in Saint Paul, MN
pros:
Wonderful co-workers who look out for each other and help when the environment is so toxic. 
Union Hospital so wages are very good.
cons: Very poor leadership starts at the top and goes down. Under staffing and no support from leaders to get new staff hired.  System is satisfied with mediocrity instead of striving for excellence. Lately on weekends we have been running out of ordered meds  from pharmacy and food in cafeteria. Very poor education opportunities, almost all education is on a computer and then when you go to put what you learn in practice the information was not correct. Lean/ VBI basis for change has got the departments so understaffed that everyone is scrambling, doing the work of at least 2 people and they still want more.

job_title: Scheduler in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Great coworkers, good pay, insurance
cons: Little advancement opportunities, stressful work

review_title: Used to be a 5 star company, now not so much
job_title: Management in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Used to be the best place in the world to work, if you are in direct patient care maybe it still is.  I would not know as I am in middle management and it is just dreadful.  See below
cons:
Out of 500 managers/directors company wide, I would guess probably 450 of them are very unhappy with how HealthEast is being led at this time.  The implementation of LEAN has turned into a grind that no one wants to do (pushed in areas where it did not even make sense), the new computer system is going to be implemented soon and nothing gets dropped off your plate and the CEO "appears"  to dislike people of any kind.
  .

review_title: Exciting at first until the realization sets in
job_title: Nutrition Services Aide in Saint Paul, MN
pros:
-Interacting with patients is definitely a plus if you are looking for experience. 
-Pay is decent but certainly comes with the cost of being expendable and slave mentality.
cons:
-Management is unfortunately unwilling to compromise. For a few of those in the senior positions, it is their way or the highway. 
-Management is very noisy concerning private/ personal issues. 
-Hiring managers consistently make poor hiring decisions which causes the workload to increase for the rest of the employees. 
-Employees are expendable

review_title: I love my job, but management is hit and miss
job_title: Registered Nurse in Saint Paul, MN
pros: HealthEast is a large healthcare organization, and the opportunities for career growth are exceptional. I've been there for 15 months now, and transferred into my perfect job 4 months ago. I feel like the senior-level leadership is very visible and engaged, though i have yet to meet our new CEO. And my Co-workers are all excellent. HealthEast attracts the best if the best when it comes to nurses. The clientele is diverse, but mostly suburban at my work sites, so no threats to my safety such as gang violence.
cons: I feel that management at times is a bloated bureaucracy. It seems they can be out of touch with the working conditions and needs of front-line clinical staff. And the best and brightest nurses typically do not go into leadership positions, because managers have little power to affect real change and spend a lot of time doing paperwork and attending meetings.

review_title: Such a toxic environment at HealthEast! Used to be good
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: A few of my co-workers still care and are good to work with. Pay is not bad.
cons: All the problems that others have written here recently is SO true. HealthEast is chaotic, negativity permeates everything, people (employees, doctors and patients) are leaving in droves. It's so dysfunctional it's almost funny. No one knows their job, management is focused on their own advancement, supposed "key priorities" change monthly, leadership tries to tout their "visions and values" to employees but everyone knows it's all lip service, their actions show that their actual values are climbing the ladder, cutting staff, dumping more and more on their employees, who are all overworked and run ragged, and taking credit for whatever they can. I have worked there for a long time and it used to be great. )-: HealthEast was actually a "Best Place to Work" a decade ago. I think sadly it would win a "Worst Place to Work" now. At least half of my department is looking for a new job and we are already way short staffed because so many have left. I would NEVER tell a friend about any open position because HealthEast is such a mess.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Maplewood, MN
pros: The people I met and had the honor to work with and call colleagues were the best thing that came out of my employment with HealthEast.
cons: I met some wonderful and supportive people during my time at HealthEast. However, the majority of leadership is out for themselves. They will say and do whatever it takes to look good and will not support staff below them. They feel the values are for everyone else except them and throw anybody under the bus that they can when they need to look good to others. This is the worst organization that I have ever been a part of and am angry that I wasted my time with them. They make empty promises when hired and then find excuses as to why they can not support you. I would never recommend anyone to this organization and will not continue to be a patient there. The pay and benefits are not up to standard level which was not a priority initially however, it does speak more towards the organization when compared to others in the field.

job_title: Information Services in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Casual dress for corporate employees. No need to travel. Fellow employees generally care for one another. Flexible schedule and ability to work from home.
cons: This organization practices LEAN/VBI, but it is the most unorganized, confusing place I have ever worked. There is no documented process for most common practices.  Employees make it up as they go and people seem to forget what was done previously each time a similar issue arises. LEAN tends to make people focus on improving small insignificant things while the big glaring issues are ignored. Corporate office facility is not an acceptable work environment with paint peeling from the walls and rats in the pipes. I read the reviews prior to accepting this position, and I wish I would not have accepted this position. It is also hard to move around here. I feel stuck. People tend to work in siloes and are hesitant to collaborate on things that they are unfamiliar with. Management does not deal with problem employees but instead sweeps issues under the rug which puts extra stress on the employees who do try their best.

review_title: HealthEast Scare System., Twin Cities, Minnesota
job_title: Storekeeper in Maplewood, MN
pros: The ability to operate this way for so long.
cons:
These employer review sites are a great idea. Obviously, the managers bad-mouthing them don’t agree, since it hinders their ability to get off on harassing and abusing their workers. They feel any worker who refuses to be a doormat is a disgruntled worker.  Potential candidates use these sites to weed out bad employers, which shows they fear it will threaten the ability of management to lure in new victims to be abused. If HealthEast management opposes it, then it must be good for workers.
The mangers I worked with have become sadistic bullies who get a perverse pleasure out of harassing and threatening innocent working people who are struggling to make a living and support their families. They abuse ‘performance reviews’ as an excuse to harass, bad-mouth and even slander their people. After the employee leaves, they use the ‘reference’ system to continue harassing and slandering their ex-employees.
 Management whines that employer review sites turn the tables and give innocent workers a chance to weed out bad and abusive employers. If you can’t take it, don’t dish it out.

review_title: “In a time of destruction, create something.”
job_title: Sterile Processing Technician in Saint Joseph, MN
pros: Okay pay, and benefits. Opportunity to grow.
cons: Allows coworkers to bully, even if it has been reported several times. There is a very bad stigma with racial personality's, that coworkers in the department I worked in. It was very disruptive to the team and myself, that I made the choice to leave! Also, if you were in the positon to become anything more than regular status, you were not supported by long time coworkers, or by certain ethnics. I am not racists! However, the stigma that heavily plagued others and myself was to intolerable! I feel it was used by persons that carried I'm a black person, and I am untouchable and if you think you are better than me, then I will use my race to manipulate, and bully you.

review_title: I am so glad I have left!
job_title: Educator in Saint Paul, MN
pros: An option for no deductible for health insurance which is nice if you have chronic issues. This is the ONLY positive thing left!
cons: After working at Healtheast for almost 13 years and not feeling like I needed  to look elsewhere, everything changed 2 years ago. My manager changed 3 times in the last 3 years. At the clinics, all of the leadership positions had to be reapplied for by everyone. With this change, Healtheast put inexperienced managers in charge in more than 1/2 of the leadership positions I worked with. There was no leadership training and very little mentoring. In my last year at the clinic, the whole place was falling apart:  employees were unhappy and leaving left and right, there was no problem solving by leadership, and no one seemed to care about me or my ideas. Very difficult to work in these conditions.

review_title: I Left HealthEast For Fairview for a Reason!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: The health systems say merging will allow them to benefit from greater efficiencies that come with size. Fairview CEO James Hereford will lead the combined organization. Fairview is much larger than HealthEast, with seven hospitals and 42 primary care clinics. HealthEast has only one-third as many clinics and four hospitals.
cons: HealthEast Care System knew beforehand they wanted to build new clinics to catch the east-side  metro’s market before merging. Limiting raises and blaming the economy for needlessly working the employees short staffed. Public documents indicate HealthEast has been struggling financially. While previous financial reports showed the business had declined over the last three years. Ratings cited weak cash flows and raised doubts that the finances would improve, noting the company's plan to boost its fortunes by going on a hiring spree by adding hundreds of doctors to its payroll. HealthEast let its employees down time after time. I thought I could forget HealthEast by going to work for Fairview. At least Fairview will be calling most of the shots!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: USED to be awesome!  When I started,  it was great. The people working in direct care are usually great, along with the departments working along with them.
cons: Way too much downsizing in areas that NEED help, dumping way too much work and not enough help into a very important office. Reading the reviews before me, and hearing the other complaints, and knowing there were ways to prevent their problems and not being able to do anything about it, except write up a VBI card and sprinkle fairy dust on it, hoping for that to work and MAYBE management would help or do something.  But nope..... Cutting benefits,  barely any raises. WAY too top heavy. Allowing so many idiots that don't care stay.

job_title: Director in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Great peers and team.  Benefits and Salary ok overall.  Other employers more competitive.  HealthEast was behind the times in many ways and very much lacked infrastructure.  The Fairview rescue will be a great improvement in many ways.  That became apparent quickly.  James Hereford is impressive and a great leader.  Hopefully that will bring some integrity to the former HealthEast.
cons: One up leader very poor.  HR sweeps things under the rug and doesn't address issues.  Lip service from upper management and not sincerity.  Once again, hopefully Fairview will help that greatly.

job_title: Anonymous in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Can collect unemployment insurance, even when managers and hr contest it.
cons: My boss had become more and more obsessed over if I'm going to get (or am) pregnant. He keeps dropping hints about being interested in my "family plan". I couldn't tell if he meant this in a friendly way, or is trying to size me up? Usually after trying to "gently discover" if I'm pregnant he will launch into a grandiose story about how his wife did not take ONE DAY of maternity leave with his kid, how she dropped him out on a Friday and was back in the office on a Monday. She couldn't understand "those women" who use babies as a way to get a vacation.  When I got my most recent review, I was shocked. Lies and exaggerations! I heard he had conversations with others trying to get their input for my review where he was trying to get them to say I was making mistakes. He just tried to make me miserable enough to quit. It worked.

job_title: CMA in Maplewood, MN
pros: Great providers to work with. Some of the staff are nice
cons: Management has their favorites and will allow them to hang out with them sit and chat with them all day or play on their phones while the rest of us do the work.  If you have an issue of not feeling comfortable doing something and bring it up you are told it will not go away.  We know that just need more training and do not get it.  Healtheast hired RNs for the clinic to help us the only thing she does is approve time cards and sit on snap chat all day in an office (they hired RNs to work on the floor and be there if the CAs need help).

job_title: EHR Analyst in Saint Paul, MN
pros:
HealthEast has always provided opportunities for me to grow and find positions that accommodate my needs. I absolutely love my job and the people I work with, and I am compensated well for my skills and take pride in my work. 

HealthEast provides generous amounts of PTO, retirement savings matching, fitness and well-being classes, and many more great benefits.
cons: Some management is hit or miss and poor managers or employees not pulling their weight are not often dealt with or moved out quickly. I would not say that this is a large problem but it exists.

review_title: Excited for HealthEast's Future with Fairview
job_title: Nurse Manager in Saint Paul, MN
pros: The announcement that Fairview is uniting with HealthEast to create the Twin Cities largest and most comprehensive care system is incredibly exciting. We get a chance to create something truly special that has size, scale and sustainability. Those joining HealthEast today will soon be able to have access to over 30,000 jobs versus the 7,000 that were available  prior to this new combination. I'm more excited about my future at HealthEast then ever before!
cons: It will be hard to take on a new identity. I am hopeful that we can be part of defining what our new combined identity will be.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Maplewood, MN
pros: Great pay and benefits.  Paid parking though NOT in a great area of town
cons: Poor manager, colleagues who were in "it" only for themselves, and ready to sell you down the river for advancement for themselves.  A physican who ALWAYS ran LATE, and was upset at those who had other opportunities after regular hours, and felt you needed to stay overtime no matter what.  And if you didn't, he cried to the Manager, and YOU got reprimanded

job_title: Family Medicine Physician in Eden Prairie, MN
pros:
- Passionate Leaders
- Focused on creating a sustainable future for our employees, our communities and our patients
- Major spending taking place on process improvement and forging new paths for community health
cons:
- Some employees would prefer we operate as independent hospitals and clinics like we used to and don't see value in a "System"
- This leads to a wide variance in engagement of team members
- Protocols and policies allow poor performers to place too much stress on their colleagues who carry their weight

job_title: CMA in Saint Paul, MN
pros:
Over all a top health company to work for.
If working in the hospital setting it is a great place to work.
cons: OutPatient clinics are run with a lot of disorganization and not professional. Most of the out patient clinics are managed with managers that don'[t have a medical back ground, therefore are run by what looks good on paper.

job_title: Management in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Co-workers are wonderful. Respected by those I work with.  High quality patient care provided to all by physicians, nurses and others.
cons: Given all the changes over the last few years and the never ending chant of "no money" we are all on edge wondering about layoffs, will we be bought by someone etc. Now National holidays have to come out of your PTO hours- very BAD idea and should be changed. No one is happy with that and the non-contract employees had no say in this decision.

job_title: CMA in Saint Paul, MN
pros: I am not really sure. Some staff and doctors are nice.
cons: The company is awful, now merged with an even worse company. Lies upon hire. Zero opportunity for advancement. They lack respect for their employees, work them to death and pay them horribly. Constant change but nothing ever gets better. Zero respect for the frontline teams who do the work, yet the leaders expect it all with no recognition.

job_title: Anonymous in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Managers are Motivated to increase ratings.
cons: Dealing with the constant uncertainty of downsizing, is not only depressing, it left me in a state of permanent adrenaline-fueled anxiety. HealthEast seems to see you as a commodity. There is no feeling of community. Everybody wonders if they are next for the chopping block, after they lowered job security and trust among employees. Then they have try to revitalize the revolving downsized organization with the latest engagement processes.

review_title: Struggling mightily with health care changes
job_title: Senior Operations Analyst in Richfield, MN
pros: Wonderful care from down to earth, intelligent, practical physicians.
cons: Continued investment in an old guard of executives that doesn't seem to be willing to face up to the changing healthcare marketplace.  Lack of drive to foresee changes and make them happen.  Healtheast is always waiting to see another system experience a success then make the same change to follow.

review_title: Gold Nugget when in actual fact it's a Dog nugget rolled in Glitter
job_title: in Saint Paul, MN
pros: I will miss some of my work-friends.
cons: I have been in my current job 10 years and am about to resign, i have watch and helped this company grow and now i am having a hard time with my health. I am being treated badly and given no support. I have been lucky in that i have a job offer from another company but it's for lower pay and a drop in rank. After reading this review site, i am now convinced that i should take the leap. I feel the higher the pay the bigger the price you pay in family, health and happiness. I want to live my life not work myself into an early grave…..we work to live not live to work ………the best things in life are free……your peace of mind is more important than you think.

job_title: Talent Acquisition in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Decent pay but not worth putting up with all of corporates shenanigans
cons: Upper management may seem transparent about the company's earnings, but you will see nothing of it, as it does not trickle down to the operations/production employees. The "ivory tower" takes care of it's own. You are constantly given "lip service" about how well everyone within the company is doing but the end result is that you do not matter. You are a number...."do your job, ask for nothing in return, and move along" is the mentality of this organization. Now they are so consumed with money that they have forgotten that happy employees will make concessions in their wok environment,  to keep a company vital. However, employees are ridden to the breaking point due to worker shortages (planned) and constant derision over not achieving impossible work expectations.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: At one time HE was a good company to work for.
cons: Management treats their employees like crap. They show favoritism toward some employees and treat others unfairly. Management seems to think it is professional to tell their female employees that they need to "Pull up their big girl panties and move on." Very hostile toward employees and very disrespectful regarding employees feelings and thoughts. Comments made by management are degrading.

job_title: Front Line Staff in Saint Paul, MN
pros:
Co-workers are able to share in the miserable atmosphere created by upper management. 
Vacation time is easy to get due to high accrual rate and ability to switch shifts with others.
cons:
Lack of compassion shown by upper management toward front line staff. 
HealthEast leadership has a "do as I say, not as I do" attitude. A recent re-branding was seen as a joke by all front line staff.

job_title: Lpn in Saint Paul, MN
pros:
Benefits
Doctors and co-workers were great!
Good hours though you were not supposed to work any overtime even though it's unavoidable
cons: The centralization of the company is a HUGE letdown to employees and patients. Took a "family" atmosphere and made it 100% impersonal. Valued long term employees were let go due to not fitting in with the new model. VERY disappointing

job_title: Cls in Saint Paul, MN
pros: This company is great to work. the people i work with are nice, some people are nasty but its ok. Im pretty sure, not everywhere, everyone will be nice.
cons: Work flow is short, they are always short on staffing. People always leaving, so that tells you that their work flow is crap. The manager is clueless, thinks he knows the work flow but put every one in stress. Hoping to leave soon.. If you want experiment then this is the place, but if you want to build your career then this is not, because they have favors and will only pick the one they like to build their career up.

job_title: Anonymous in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Everybody is themselves when its not so busy.
cons:
Poor communication within and across departments and teams.

- Very political. Politics over logic, professionalism, and work ethics. Whether you can do a good job, finish your work on time, or have the knowledge to do the work is much less important than you getting along with people and being liked by your supervisor and key people in the company.

- People there do not understand what professionalism is. From HR to most of management. Most of them are not on top of and do not resolve issues (production or management issues). They have tons of meetings to talk about it and only to come out of those meetings to do nothing.

review_title: New CEO Getting a Bad Rap!
job_title: Former Corporate Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Health Care changes taking place!
cons: Healtheast care system has never been a good place to work, at least while I was there. The long- term employee's ruled the system and if they didn't like you, watch out! Management and Leadership positions were historically ingrained with cronyism and ran on the  good-old-boy system. I feel sorry for the new CEO, she was her work cut out for her. Its gonna take years to get the place in order (after-all it took years and years to get the organization so dysfunctional)  and ready for the new generation of employee's. Hopefully she will retire the cronies (goodbye and good riddance to them and their long-line of family and friends).

job_title: Clinical Analyst (Health Informatics/Statistics) in Saint Paul, MN
pros: My Team and cube mates
cons: HealthEast has cut benefits, scheduled staff for 80 hour weeks and paid them for 40, while you are bleeding your PTO. Expectations on staff are unrealistic, exploits hard work and dedication. They expect you to work long hours, expect to use your cell phone for call yet offer no stipend for doing so. Pay you $1.50 an hour for call (seriously). I am aware of many looking for the door.   Maybe if there was a thank you! I don't know, you get yelled at by Doctors , Nurses, Leads,and no support from managers.

job_title: Coordinator in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Benefits were decent, there used to be opportunity to move around within the organization, multiple locations to choose from in the St. Paul area.
cons: Upper management wasn't good at dealing with issues, lots of passive/aggressive behavior, communication practices weren't good and often last minute, changes within the organization didn't seem to be thought out very well before being implemented, and changes were being made too frequently.

review_title: Dead end registered nurse position with very high expectations for perfection, scrutinized by management.
job_title: Registered Nurse in Saint Paul, MN
pros: RN salary, as it is union and co-workers
cons:
unsolid leadership
judged for performance unfairly
high use of fad healthcare initiatives to cater to the clients

job_title: Manager in Saint Paul, MN
pros: I was a long term employee that loved my job and did it well, throughout my years of service I was promoted several times. I have now moved on to another health care system that reminds me of what Healtheast used to be.
cons: VBI was introduced to the company and moral decreased. Leadership was concerned and awarded for the quantity of VBI cards submitted by employees and not the quality. I had a direct report that was only concerned about themselves and their bonus.They would talk about my co-workers inappropriately and had favorites. The "lean" concept produced layoffs of long term employees that were dedicated to the company.

job_title: Sterile Processing Technician in Maplewood, MN
pros: Small hospital with lots of opportunities to work overtime, education reimbursement, lots of online employee resources. Close knit teams environment.
cons: Lots of "lifer" employees with the "we've always done it that way" attitude, outdated and crowded conditions, mandatory union membership. Lots of surprises due to poor communication.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: According to state law, employees can review and get copies of their personnel records, every six months!
cons: I was severely overworked and the environment was so chaotic that nobody seemed like they knew what was going on. We were short staffed most of the time. The patients complained to us as if we had any control over the situation. I've been told over and over again on how things are going to improve, but management  just pushed the duties around. I decided to look elsewhere to further my career in the direction I wanted it to go. If I thought this place was getting better...I would still be there!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Maplewood, MN
pros: staff, co workers bond together, we don't utilize the leader and seek things our self. hard working managers, and directors stick together.
cons: upper leadership (service line level)  in organization do not respect or appreciate their managers/directors. Trust is a major factor.  Alot of work put on shoulders of management. Constant reorgs done, putting us all on edge. Less staff around, more work to be done without support of upper leadership.

job_title: Corporate in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Used to be better, but always struggling. Lots of good people to work with.  There was a common mission of doing what is right for the patient.
cons: Ship has been struggling to afloat for  a few years. Executive leaders are like the musicians on the deck in the Titanic, trying to calm the few staff left as work them like crazy so they keep the boat afloat. The new leaders are toxic. Workplace violence is commonplace. They will use you and offer nothing in return. Trust and respect are words, used in marketing only.

job_title: Physical Therapist in Saint Paul, MN
pros: My direct managers were very friendly and helpful.  We had a good team and tried to help each other out when possible
cons: In my opinion the company was much less employee friendly when the new CEO came in.  The is constant change due to the lean flow management model.

job_title: Anonymous in Saint Paul, MN
pros: OK compensation and benefits,,,meets industry standards.
cons: Start your day feeling one-two hours behind and drilled with the word "team" .........the saying there is no i in team does not apply, as i is the team. Not that your co-workers don't want to help you but they are running on their hamster wheel as fast as you are. The hardest part of the job is knowing no matter how hard you try or care when you are asked to come the to the manager’s office you know it's not for a job well done pat on the back.

job_title: Anonymous in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Love most of my co workers
cons: Pay is below most healthcare systems. Told we will get Fairview pay soon. Not holding my breath. Favoritism in the department causes problems with other staff members.  Don’t feel they care about the employees because they feel there is a surplus of workers out there. Hiring people who are lazy and then they do not get rid of them.

review_title: St. John's Hospital: Nice place to work
job_title: Registered Nurse in Maplewood, MN
pros: Medium sized community hospital, felt safe. Doctors: Friendly hospitalists, more friendly surgeons than not, excellent oncology MDs. Great teamwork among staff, fellow RNs are kind, knowledgable, and helpful. Good staffing ratios, generally 4 patients to a nurse for day and evening shifts.
cons: McKesson charting system was poor, not user friendly. They are in the process of shopping for a new vender. Discharge process was inefficent and frustrating.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros:
Ways to Wellness fitness program
good mileage reimbursement
good IT support system
frontline staff are very dedicated

Attendance policy is rigid and inflexible

VBI system is frustrating and translates into more work

job_title: Lab Technician in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Nice coworkers most of the time, but when it gets crazy busy people get angry with each other.
cons: I started HealthEast  Care System with an above average wage, but I soon figured out in the long run the wage was actually a lot less than average, because I haven't received a cost of living increase in the last five years I worked there. The benefits aren't what they seem and you have to know the right person to get promotions. I moved on to advance my career and goals.

job_title: Corporate in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Not a whole lot. The cafeterias maybe. Most management in administration are clueless. They don't listen to anyone below them.
cons: Clueless management. Lean initiatives are tiresome and beat to death. Will get bought out or merge with other local hospital system in the near future.

review_title: once a good company, now run by incompetent fools
job_title: Registered Nurse in South Saint Paul, MN
pros:
When I began working at Healtheast in 2006 it was a wonderful place to work. The atmosphere was very positive and employees were treated fairly and with respect. 
Pay is competitive. In line with the average pay for type of work, area, etc..
Good health insurance, dental benefits at a reasonable cost.
cons: In 2009 corporate became more involved in our department (after hours phone triage) looking for cost savings. They began micromanaging and cut staff to the bare minimum. This resulted in our excellent manager leaving the company. The next manager was inexperienced though I believe she tried to manage the many new projects thrust upon her as best as she could. In 2014, Healtheast brought in managers that were incompetent, very authoritarian and disrespectful toward many nurses. Some nurses were immune. Management had their favorites and their scapegoats. Staffing was a complete mess. We were short almost every shift and little was done to remedy this. The manager refused to help with triage as past managers had done. Nurses were forced to work double shifts sometimes overnight (3-11pm then 11pm to 7am) due to sick calls that left us with no night RN. Management again refused to step up to the plate and take responsibility for the department and the staffing woes we had which were due to their incompetence. Then when patients were unhappy with wait times or if lower priority patients received less attention, our manager would reprimand us for it.  Though she refused to assist the nurses or to remedy the staffing shortage, our manager was quick to write nurses up for even trivial matters, anything that bothered her really, with no sense of equal treatment for all. One evening an RN was forced to work alone on the busiest night of the week. This was not due to sick calls but due to vacation time being granted to all the other nurses scheduled that night. One of these was a last minute vacation request that our manager approved knowing this would put only one RN working that shift. Normal scheduling for such a shift is 4 nurses and even then it is challenging. This nurse worked that shift alone and received no support or direction from management whatsoever. Phone calls and e-mails were unreturned. Several days later our manager went looking for problems and mistakes from that shift. This nurse was terminated after eight years of employment in good standing because of a minor error (which did not result in any harm) made while severely understaffed (by herself).  Other nurses were threatened with termination over equally minor instances.  Healtheast's reputation in the medical community and among patients has deteriorated.

job_title: Licensed Alcohol and Drug Counselor in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Good pay, great benefits, awesome coworkers. I really enjoyed my experience with Healtheast. I learned a lot from the amazing people who work there and grew as a person.
cons: Lacks management, difficult to make necessary changes within the organization. I wish Healtheast was more open to positive changes within the organization.

review_title: Very unstable, frustrating toxic environment - used to be great
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Competitive pay. There are some happy, decently functioning teams throughout the organization, particularly if you avoid corporate positions.
cons:
HE was celebrating one of many consecutive "Best Places to Work" awards when I joined 10 years ago. Sadly, I believe if there was a "Worst Places," they would be a top contender today. Turnover is sky high, layoffs are high, positions are eliminated and then rehired months later  (re-titled) frequently. On my team, 10 of the 14 employees were all hired within the past year, due to people leaving or getting bullied out. Some departments have such dysfunction that they change their names because employees have a bad association with "such and such department," rather than fixing the root causes. Employee morale is incredibly low. I have read other reviews here about HE "heading in the right direction." Unfortunately I have never encountered that sentiment from anyone except those pushing the corporate initiative-of-the-day.

If you are thinking of taking a job at HE, my advice is don't. If you insist on considering it, I would recommend asking questions about the department make-up/how long most of the people have been there, etc. Long-term doesn't always equal better, but in the case of HE, my experience is that the departments with the most new employees are the ones where the most problems exist. (An exception would be areas directly related to Epic, because they legitimately did add a lot of personnel.)

I expect/hope to leave. I've waited 3 years for a turn-around and it just keeps getting worse year by year!

review_title: Great coworkers and teamwork - less than great leadership
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Good health benefits, graduated PTO accrual based on length of time with company. Most employees I've encountered at 2 different sites have been excellent coworkers.
cons: Major disconnect between upper management and mid to low level employees. Leadership makes knee-jerk decisions to cut costs which hurts the organization in the long run and the employees that remain have to shoulder more and more responsibility and stress

job_title: HUC in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Hospice!!!!!   Amazing, wonderful people.  Without them I would have been so lost in the last 2 - 3 months of my mom’s life.  Thank you.  Also the aftercare for the family has been caring, even when I deny depression, I know they are there.
cons:
Certain supervisors in the CD/Mental Health units have no problems with throwing subordinates under the bus to make her look better, and tell outright lies regarding employees.  Yes this is personal.

I worked for HE for 10 years and was let go because I chose to stay home with my mom who was end stage breast cancer.  My boss encouraged and even suggested I have some personal things taken care of even if it took more time. 

When the time to go back came around my boss, HR and I talked on the phone, I wasn't ready to come back as my mom was worse every day and her Onc. told her there was nothing else they could do.  I reminded my boss of her recommending I work on myself and she denied it to HR.  After that I received letters from HR stating I never called to discuss my status even though I called my boss at least 6 times and left voice mail with her and twice to her asst, no calls were ever returned.  I told HR about this but they believed the director as they are suppose to, but this gives no non-union employees no power and that is sad, 

Oh one funny thing,  every month for 4 or 5 months, I received a letter from HR stating I was fired because I did not call my boss,  after the first letter, I left one last voicemail saying I would not be back until after my mom passed (which as in March 2015}.  I got this same letter monthly starting in October and ending in Jan or Feb.   I have no idea what they were trying to accomplice with this

From my perspective HE has little to no employee support.  I would not work for them again and they are missing out because I was great at my job.

job_title: Sterile Processing Technician in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Try's to market HealthEasts Christian values.
cons: HealthEast Care System tries to use performance improvement plans to abuse and force out workers. They claim to be a Christian organization but show no Christian morals in how they treat their employees. You will probably get a bad feeling after working there only a short time. Trust the feeling, the managers treat people like dirt and they hide behind a mask of "Christian values" that looks like nothing more than a lie.

review_title: Avoid! The stress and low pay isn't worth it.
job_title: Clinic Manager in Maplewood, MN
pros: Large health system with lots of room for job advancement. Health insurance benefits are affordable.
cons: Poorly managed. Their servant leadership model results in managers and leads often having their hands tied and bending to the wills of their employees. Leadership is poorly supported when making needed decisions or changes. One of the worst cultures I have ever worked in. Upper management is quick to criticize but not provide direction for improvement or an action plan. They are too embedded in a grey area, and feelings, and unable to make concrete choices and guidance. Pay is low for managers and leads.

job_title: Senior Business Operations Analyst in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Great people to work with, but at this point the good people don't outweigh the bad.
cons: Management does little to grow its staff professionally. Lack of direction among the constant restructure of leadership and continued elimination of various leaders. Stop using Lean to run the business, it gets in the way of doing your day to day job and adds unnecessary work and no added value.

job_title: in Saint Paul, MN
pros: I enjoy the outdoor patio.
cons: The Director where I work aggressively promotes company values that don’t seem to match day-to-day events.For example, clear communication is preached in elaborate seminars while poor communication continues to be the norm. Valuing and respecting others is publicized in the company mission statement, or on framed motivational posters near the doors, but undermining and belittling others seems pervasive. Everyone is told to make company goals their first priority and adopt a spirit of teamwork, but internal competition dominates. Worst of all, the most consistent violators of company values are the most highly rewarded.
